awd_titl_txt: The Southern Ocean's Iron Cycle through the Cenozoic
awd_abstract_narration:
Iron limits primary productivity in the modern Southern Ocean. This, in turn, reduces the amount of atmospheric carbon dioxide that is taken up by the high-latitude oceans. These observations raise a number of fascinating and hitherto unanswered questions, namely: what are the major sources of iron to the Southern Ocean? How resilient or variable is the supply of iron from these sources over geologic time? How has the iron cycle responded to long-term changes in Earth's climate? Have changes in the iron cycle influenced those of other nutrients, such as silica? This project will address these questions by means of a multifaceted approach examining the origin of the sediment, deposition rates, and quantification of iron sources therein. The detailed records obtained will be used to examine how changes in ocean nutrient cycles relate to the major tectonic, climatic, and biogeochemical reorganizations that have occurred over the past 66 million years ago. The holistic framework used will consider the interplay of these major Earth system processes and quantify their individual roles in shaping iron delivery to the largest iron-limited biome on Earth. 

This project will quantify the major sources of iron to the Southern Ocean and how they changed in space and time, based on the geochemistry of metal-rich deep-sea clay sequences drilled by the International Ocean Discovery Program. This will be achieved by combining statistical modeling of the origin of the clay with radiometrically-constrained deposition rates and explicit quantification of iron sources therein. The resultant reconstructions will be used to test hypotheses regarding: the significance of hydrothermally-derived iron to the high-latitude oceans over the Cenozoic; how the opening of tectonic gateways redistributed deeply-sourced iron within the Southern Ocean; how the supply of dust-derived iron changed as Australia became a desert; and, if there were changes in the iron cycle associated with the proliferation of diatoms. This project complements ongoing research conducted as part of the GEOTRACES program, will engage K-12 students from communities underrepresented in STEM, and will support two early-career researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Pelagic clays, covering nearly half of the ocean floor, serve as valuable archives for tracking changes in the iron cycle over millions of years, allowing scientists to study the history of iron in the ocean and its link to global climate changes. Our team developed a new method to disentangle the various processes influencing iron isotopes in marine sediments, using a multivariate statistical approach that identified four distinct sources of iron in the sediment record, thereby enhancing our understanding of their historical variability. We also advanced the use of osmium isotopes for dating and correlating layers of pelagic clays, which improved the accuracy of age models and identified previously undetected periods of non-deposition. By constructing detailed records of iron cycle changes in the high-latitude South Pacific during the Cenozoic era, we provided new insights into the iron cycle’s response to climatic shifts over millions of years. Additionally, we demonstrated that recently deposited marine sediments can effectively capture overlying water column processes using iron isotope proxies, bridging the gap between modern seawater chemistry and sediment deposits.

 

Broader Impacts

The insights from this project contribute to understanding the stability and variability of the iron cycle over long timescales, which is crucial for minerals critical to national wellbeing. For example, there is significant international interest in mining polymetallic nodules from the seafloor to supply modern technologies with essential metals, such that understanding iron and manganese distributions becomes vital. This project supported an early career scientist during her transition to a tenure-track position, helping establish and sustain her research program, refine lab methods, and enhance her mentoring experience. It also provided support for two female graduate students, providing them with valuable experience in sample preparation, analysis, and presenting their work at major conferences. Additionally, the project provided opportunities for two undergraduate summer students from communities underrepresented in the geosciences to engage in research, present their findings at conferences, and pursue further education in the field. Educational outreach included exchanges between WHOI and a local high school that serves students predominantly from communities underrepresented in the geosciences. The PI engaged with students and facilitated visits to WHOI for hands-on scientific activities, aiming to inspire and educate students in the marine and Earth sciences.

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2024
Modified by: Ann Dunlea
